item.description:
The Center for Astrophysics (CfA) at the Harvard-Smithsonian Observatory is bringing back their popular program about good and bad science at the movies. This event (and the one on Thursday, May 5, 2011) is part of the 2011 Cambridge Science Festival. Tonight's movie is Moon. David Aguilar of the CfA Public Affairs office will introduce the film.

This event takes place at 7:30 p.m. on Friday, May 6, at Phillips Auditorium, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge. Doors open at 7:00 p.m., but get there early . . . even before 6:45 p.m. Seating is first-come, first-served for the main lecture room. Admission is free.

Free parking is available to everyone after 5 p.m. (Ignore the "staff only" signs.) Drive up to the back, up the hill. The presentation is up the stairs that are opposite the observatory-in-a-box. Mass Ave buses (to points in Arlington and North Cambridge) originate in Harvard Square on the Red Line and travel along Massachusetts Avenue, which is about a 10-minute walk from the auditorium.

For more information and directions, go to http://www.dva.harvard.edu/events or call 617.495.7461.

A line forms early for this event. Please do not cut in line because we will meet inside the auditorium: go to the back left of the seats. Sitting at the left rear of the lecture hall is a way to let people find me and an empty seat that much more easily.

If people would like to go out after the movie, we'll go to the Algiers Coffee House, 40 Brattle Street, Harvard Square, Cambridge.

From the CfA:

Sci-fi Movie Night
Friday, May 6, 2011, 7:30 p.m., Moon (Introduction by David Aguilar)

 

 

For my [David Aguilar’s] pick as my favorite recent sci-fi movie, I chose Moon by Duncan Jones. Released in June 2009, this British film begins where the exploration of the Moon in 2001: A Space Odyssey left off, exploring scientific and ethical questions of a possible world to come. Amazingly, like 2001, no computer graphics were used. Working out the final days of his three-year mining contract, Sam Bell (actor Sam Rockwell) is close to cracking from loneliness. Talking to loved ones via video link isn't enough. Then one day, while out making repairs, he discovers something that shatters his life. This movie also stars Kevin Spacey and is rated R for language.

 

For the Cambridge Science Festival, we’re bringing back our popular program, “Everything I learned about science, I learned at the movies,” which takes a look at the good and bad science in popular science-fiction films. . . .
